ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:0.5_0: The training rule on fewer than five mends
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying in the Sakyan country at Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.1.2_0: At that time a potter had invited the monks:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.1.4_0: But the monks lacked a sense of moderation, and they asked for many bowls.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.1.5_0: Those who had small bowls asked for large bowls,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.1.6_0: and those who had large bowls asked for small bowls.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.1.7_0: The potter was so busy making bowls for the monks that he was unable to make other goods for sale.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.1.8_0: He could not make a living for himself, and his wives and children suffered.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.1.9_0: People complained and criticized the monks,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.1.10_0: “How can the Sakyan ascetics not have any sense of moderation and ask for many bowls?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.1.11_0: This potter is so busy making bowls for them that he is unable to make other goods for sale.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.1.12_0: He is unable to make a living for himself, and his wives and children are suffering.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.1.13_0: The monks heard the complaints of those people
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.1.14_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Udāyī,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.1.15_0: “How can those monks not have a sense of moderation and ask for many bowls?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.1.16_0: After rebuking those monks in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.1.17_0: “Is it true, monks, that some monks are acting like this?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.1.20_0: “... How can those foolish men not have a sense of moderation and ask for many bowls?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.1.21_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.1.22_0: after criticizing them, he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.1.23_0: “You should not ask for an almsbowl.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.2.1_0: Soon afterwards the bowl of a certain monk broke.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.2.2_0: Knowing that the Buddha had prohibited asking for a bowl and being afraid of wrongdoing, he did not ask for a new one.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.2.3_0: As a consequence he collected almsfood with his hands.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.2.4_0: People complained and criticized the monks,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.2.5_0: “How can the Sakyan ascetics collect almsfood with their hands, just like the ascetics of other religions?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.2.6_0: The monks heard the complaints of those people
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.2.8_0: After giving a teaching, the Buddha addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.2.9_0: “Monks, I allow you to ask for a new almsbowl if your bowl has been lost or is broken.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.3.1_0: At that time the monks from the group of six knew that the Buddha had given permission by the monks from the group of six could not ask for many bowls or their existing bowls for many bowls.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.3.2_0: The potter was so busy making bowls for the monks that he was unable to make other goods for sale.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.3.3_0: He could not make a living for himself, and his wives and children suffered.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.3.5_0: “How can the Sakyan ascetics not have any sense of moderation and ask for many bowls?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.3.6_0: This potter is so busy making bowls for them that he’s unable to make goods for sale. He can’t make a living for himself, and his wives and children are suffering.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.3.7_0: The monks heard the complaints of those people
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.3.8_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Udāyī,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.3.9_0: “How can the monks from the group of six ask for many bowls even if their existing bowls only have a minor chip or scratch?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.3.10_0: After criticizing those monks in many ways, they told the Buddha ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.3.11_0: “Is it true, monks, that you do this?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.3.14_0: “... Foolish men, how can you ask for many bowls even if your existing bowls only have a minor chip or scratch?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.3.15_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...” ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.3.16_0: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.3.17.1_0: ‘If a monk exchanges an almsbowl with fewer than five mends for a new almsbowl, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.3.18_0: That monk should relinquish that almsbowl to a gathering of monks.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:1.3.19_0: He should then be given the last almsbowl belonging to that gathering: ‘Monk, this bowl is yours; keep it until it breaks.’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.4_0: ...The monk who has been given the full ordination by a unanimous Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.5_0: An almsbowl with fewer than five mends:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.6_0: it has no mends, one mend, two mends, three mends, or four mends.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.7_0: An almsbowl with a mend that does not count:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.8_0: he cannot go to the fingernail,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.9_0: A almsbowl with a mend that counts:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.12_0: asked for is what is meant.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.14_0: If he asks for, then for the effort there is an act of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.15_0: When he gets it, it becomes subject to relinquishment.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.16_0: It should be relinquished in the midst of the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.17_0: All determined bowls should be brought together.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.18_0: You should not determine an inferior bowl, thinking,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.20_0: If you determine an inferior bowl, thinking, “I’ll get a valuable bowl,” you commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.21_0: “And, monks, it’s to be relinquished like this.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.22_0: After approaching the Sangha, that monk should put his upper robe over one shoulder and pay respect at the feet of the senior monks. He should then squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and say:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.23_0: ‘Venerables, this almsbowl with fewer than five mends is to be relinquished.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.24_0: I relinquish it to the Sangha.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.25_0: After relinquishing it, he is to confess the offense.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.26_0: The confession should be received by a competent and capable monk.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.27_0: A monk who has five qualities should be appointed as the distributor of almsbowls:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.28_0: he is not swayed by desire, ill will, confusion, or fear, and he knows what has and has not been allocated.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.29_0: “And, monks, this is how he should be appointed.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.30_0: First a monk should be asked
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.31_0: and then a competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.32_0: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.33_0: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, the Sangha should appoint monk so-and-so as the distributor of almsbowls.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.35_0: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.36_0: The Sangha appoints monk so-and-so as the distributor of almsbowls.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.37_0: Any monk who approves of appointing monk so-and-so as the distributor of almsbowls should remain silent.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.38_0: Any monk who doesn’t agree should speak up.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.39_0: The Sangha has appointed monk so-and-so as the distributor of almsbowls.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.40_0: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.42_0: The appointed monk should give away that bowl.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.45_0: If the most senior monk takes it, his bowl should be offered to the next monk.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.46_0: If he doesn’t, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.47_0: It is not to be offered to anyone who does not have bowl.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.48_0: In this manner it should be offered all the way to the most junior monk in the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.49_0: He is then to be given the last bowl belonging to that gathering of monks: “Monk, this bowl is yours; keep it until it breaks”:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.50_0: That monk is not to store that bowl in an unsuitable place, to use it in an unsuitable way, or to give it away, thinking, “How may this bowl be lost, destroyed, or broken?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np22:2.1.51_0: If he stores it in an unsuitable place, uses it in an unsuitable way, or gives it away, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.”
